normalised: What are some surprisingly effective training regimens you have seen or used in Indian sports?

unnormalised: **What are some surprisingly effective training regimens you've seen or used in Indian sports?**
normalised: So, I have seen some truly inspiring (and sometimes, frankly, bizarre) training regimens while coaching kabaddi in my village near Varanasi. It’s not all fancy gyms and protein shakes like you see in I P L.

unnormalised: So, I've seen some truly inspiring (and sometimes, frankly, bizarre) training regimens while coaching kabaddi in my village near Varanasi. It’s not all fancy gyms and protein shakes like you see in IPL.
normalised: One that sticks out involves waking up at zero four hundred hours every morning (yes, even during Diwali!) for "danda baithak" – traditional Indian push-ups and squats. Our Guruji swore it built incredible core strength and endurance for those long raids.

unnormalised: One that sticks out involves waking up at 04:00 hrs every morning (yes, even during Diwali!) for "danda baithak" – traditional Indian push-ups and squats. Our Guruji swore it built incredible core strength and endurance for those long raids.
normalised: Another coach I know, Mister Sharma from Chandigarh University, swears by hill sprints. He takes his hockey team up to Shivalik Hills every Sunday. He says that doing five kilometer of those sprints is more effective than any gym workout. He’s got this theory about building mental fortitude alongside physical strength. Makes sense, right?

normalised: Then there’s the classic "Malkhamb" training. Its origins are firmly rooted in the Indian subcontinent. I’ve seen wrestlers and even cricketers like Virat Kohli incorporating it for agility and flexibility. It's seriously intense!

normalised: I remember back in two thousand and ten, my cousin, a state-level badminton player, was forced by his coach to meditate for thirty minutes before and after every practice session (which itself started at sixteen hundred hours). At first, he hated it, but he later admitted it dramatically improved his focus and reaction time on the court.

normalised: Finally, don't underestimate the power of diet. My grandmother always said "What you eat is what you are."
